member.name: M:Catkeys.Api.strtoi(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts part of string to int. Returns the int value. Returns 0 if the string is null, "" or does not begin with a number; then numberEndIndex will be = startIndex. Returns int.MaxValue or int.MinValue if the value is not in int range; then numberEndIndex will also include all number characters that follow the valid part.
member.param: String.
Offset in string where to start parsing.
Receives offset in string where the number part ends.

If 0, parses the string as hexadecimal number if begins with "0x", as octal if begins with "0", else as decimal. Else it can be 2 to 36. Examples: 10 - parse as decimal (don't support "0x" etc); 16 - as hexadecimal (eg returns 26 if string is "1A" or "0x1A"); 2 - as binary (eg returns 5 if string is "101").
member.exception: startIndex is invalid.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Api.strtoui(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts part of string to uint. Returns the uint value. Returns 0 if the string is null, "" or does not begin with a number; then numberEndIndex will be = startIndex. Returns uint.MaxValue (0xffffffff) or uint.MinValue (0) if the value is not in uint range; then numberEndIndex will also include all number characters that follow the valid part. Supports negative number values -1 to -int.MaxValue, for example converts string "-1" to 0xffffffff.
member.param: String.
Offset in string where to start parsing.
Receives offset in string where the number part ends.

If 0, parses the string as hexadecimal number if begins with "0x", as octal if begins with "0", else as decimal. Else it can be 2 to 36. Examples: 10 - parse as decimal (don't support "0x" etc); 16 - as hexadecimal (eg returns 26 if string is "1A" or "0x1A"); 2 - as binary (eg returns 5 if string is "101").
member.exception: startIndex is invalid.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Native
member.summary: Windows API types and constants used with public functions (parameters etc) of this library. Also several helper functions.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Native.ClearError
member.summary: Calls API SetLastError(0), which clears the Windows API error code of this thread. Need it before calling some functions if you want to use or GetErrorText.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Native.GetError
member.summary: Gets the Windows API error code of this thread. Calls .
member.remarks:
Many Windows API functions, when failed, set an error code. Code 0 means no error. It is stored in an internal thread-specific int variable. Some functions of this library simply call these API functions and don't throw exception when API fail. For example, most Wnd propery-get functions. When failed, they return false/0/null/empty. Then you can call Native.GetError if you want to know whether the function failed or/and what is the error code. Also you can use GetErrorText.
Most of these functions set the code only when failed, and don't clear old error code when succeeded. Therefore may need to call before.
Windows API error code definitions and documentation are not included in this library. You can look for them in API function documentation on the internet.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Native.GetErrorText
member.summary: Gets the text message of the Windows API error code of this thread. Returns null if the code is 0.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Native.GetErrorText(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the text message of a Windows API error code. Returns null if errorCode is 0.

member.name: T:Catkeys.InterDomain
member.summary: Inter-domain variables. Allows to share values by all app domains of this process. Similar to environment variables, but supports more types and does not inherit parent process variables; the speed is similar. Supports not all types. The type must have one of these properties: 1. Derived from MarshalByRefObject. The stored value is a virtual reference (proxy), not a copy. The owner domain must be still alive when other domains access (call methods etc) the retrieved value, else AppDomainUnloadedException. 2. Has [Serializable] attribute. The stored value is a copy, not reference. For example int, IntPtr, string, arrays, List, Dictionary.

member.name: M:Catkeys.InterDomain.SetVariable(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Adds or modifies an inter-domain variable.
member.param: Name. Can be any unique string, for example a GUID string. Case-sensitive.
Value.
member.exception: The type is not supported because is neither serializable nor MarshalByRefObject-derived.

member.name: M:Catkeys.InterDomain.GetVariable(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the value of an inter-domain variable. Returns null if the variable does not exist. Else returns the value as object; need a cast.
member.param: Name. Case-sensitive.

member.name: M:Catkeys.InterDomain.GetVariable``1(System.String,``0@)
member.summary: Gets the value of an inter-domain variable. Returns true if the variable exists and is not null.
member.param: Name. Case-sensitive.
Receives the value. If the variable does not exist, receives the default value of that type.
member.exception: Value type mismatch.

member.name: M:Catkeys.InterDomain.GetVariable``1(System.String,System.Func{``0})
member.summary: Gets the value of an inter-domain variable. If the variable does not exist or is null, calls a callback function that provides an initial value; then sets the variable = the initial value. Thread-safe.
member.param: Name. Case-sensitive.
A callback function delegate (eg lambda) that is called when the variable does not exist or is null. It must return an initial value.
member.exception: The type is not supported because is neither serializable nor MarshalByRefObject-derived.
Value type mismatch.

example.code: int test = InterDomain.GetVariable("test", () => 10);

member.name: M:Catkeys.InterDomain.DefaultDomainVariable``1(System.String,``0@)
member.summary: Gets a reference to an object that lives in default app domain. Auto-creates new object there if does not exist. The object can be used in any app domain. When a non-default domain calls its methods, the call is marshaled to the default domain and executed there. The type must be derived from MarshalByRefObject and have default constructor. Returns true if created new object, false if it already existed. Thread-safe.
member.param: Inter-domain variable name. Any unique string. Case-sensitive.
Receives the reference.

member.name: T:Catkeys.WndException
member.summary: Exception thrown mostly by functions, when invalid window handle and when fails for other reasons.
member.remarks: This class is based on . The Message property can include a custom string (if set) and a Windows API error message (if error code not 0). If the error code is ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE, Message returns a more specific text that depends on whether the window handle is 0. If constructor parameter 'code' is 0 and the window is invalid, instead uses ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE. Adds period characters if need. If the string passed to the constructor starts with "*", replaces the "*" with "Failed to ". If ends with "*", replaces the "*" with " window.".

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types`2
member.summary: Used for method parameters that accept one of two types.
member.remarks:
Some methods have one or several parameters that must be one of several types. There are several ways of implementing such functions. 1. Overloaded methods. However some programmers often don't like it, because in some cases need to create many overloads, then maintain their documentation. Also then method users have to spend much time to find the correct overload. 2. Generic methods. However in most cases the compiler cannot protect from using an unsupported type. Also then method users don't see the allowed types instantly in intellisense. 3. Using the Object type for the parameter. However then the compiler does not protect from using an unsupported type. Also then method users don't see the allowed types instantly in intellisense. Also slower, especially with value types (need boxing). 4. Using this type for the parameter. It does not have the above problems.
When a parameter is of type Types<T1, T2>, method users can pass only values of type T1 or T2, else compiler error. They see the allowed types instantly in intellisense. Also there are similar types that can be used to support more parameter types:
To support null (for example for optional parameters), use nullable. See examples.

member.name: T:Catkeys.LPARAM
member.summary: Similar to IntPtr (can be 32-bit or 64-bit), but more useful for usually-non-pointer values, eg wParam/lParam of SendMessage. Unlike IntPtr: Has implicit casts from/to most integral types. Does not check overflow when casting from uint etc. IntPtr throws exception on overflow, which can create strange bugs.
member.remarks: There is no struct WPARAM. Use LPARAM instead, because it is the same in all cases except when casting to long or ulong (ambigous signed/unsigned). There is no cast operators for enum. When need, cast through int or uint. For Wnd cast through IntPtr.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Folders
member.summary: Gets special folder paths (Desktop, Temp, etc). Most functions return special folder paths. Actually the return value is of type Folders.FolderPath, but it is implicitly convertible to string. The Folders.FolderPath type has operator + that appends a filename or relative path string; it also appends @"\" if need, processes @"..\" etc and returns fully-qualified path string. Example: string s=Folders.Desktop+"file.txt"; If a function cannot get special folder path, the return value contains null string. Then the above-mentioned + operator throws CatException. Some special folders exist only on newer Windows versions or not on all computers. The property-get functions have names of special folders (or similar), some with a suffix like "_Win8" which means that the folder is unavailable in older Windows versions. Note: some known folders, although supported and registerd, may be still not created. Some special folders are virtual, for example Control Panel. They don't have a file system path, but can be identified by an unmanaged array of bytes called "ITEMIDLIST" or "PIDL". Functions of the nested class 'VirtualIDLIST' return the PIDL as IntPtr; you must free it with Marshal.FreeCoTaskMem(). Functions of the nested class 'Virtual' return the ITEMIDLIST as string "<idlist:Base64_encoded_ITEMIDLIST>" that can be used with some functions of this library but not with .NET or native functions. Most functions use Windows "Known Folders" API, such as SHGetKnownFolderPath.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Folders.Temp
member.summary: Temp (temporary files) folder of current user account.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Folders.ThisApp
member.summary: Folder containing assemblies of current app domain. Calls .
member.remarks: Unlike , this path can be different for each app domain; it is set when creating the AppDomain. See also , it gets full path (with file name) of current app domain's main/entry assembly.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Folders.ThisAppTemp
member.summary: Gets or sets path of the temporary files folder of this application. Default is Folders.Temp + Application.CompanyName + "\\" + Application.ProductName. The 'set' function does not change system settings, it just remembers a string that will be later returned by the 'get' function. The 'get' function creates the folder if does not exist.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Folders.ThisAppDocuments
member.summary: Gets or sets path of user document files folder of this application. Default is Folders.Documents + Application.CompanyName + "\\" + Application.ProductName. The 'set' function does not change system settings, it just remembers a string that will be later returned by the 'get' function. The 'get' function creates the folder if does not exist.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Folders.ThisAppData
member.summary: Gets or sets path of private files folder of this application on this user account. Default is Folders.RoamingAppData + Application.CompanyName + "\\" + Application.ProductName. The 'set' function does not change system settings, it just remembers a string that will be later returned by the 'get' function. The 'get' function creates the folder if does not exist.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Folders.ThisAppDataLocal
member.summary: Gets or sets path of local (non-roaming) private files folder of this application on this user account. Default is Folders.LocalAppData + Application.CompanyName + "\\" + Application.ProductName. The 'set' function does not change system settings, it just remembers a string that will be later returned by the 'get' function. The 'get' function creates the folder if does not exist.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Folders.ThisAppDataCommon
member.summary: Gets or sets path of common (all users) private files folder of this application. Default is Folders.ProgramData + Application.CompanyName + "\\" + Application.ProductName. The 'set' function does not change system settings, it just remembers a string that will be later returned by the 'get' function. Note: the ProgramData folder has special permissions. Programs running not as administrator usually cannot write there. This function does not auto-create the folder; usually it is created when installing the application.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Folders.ThisProcess
member.summary: Folder containing current process program file. Calls . Unlike , this path is the same for all app domains running in this process.

member.summary: Gets object of the screen that contains the specified window (the biggest part of it) or is nearest to it. If w handle is 0 or invalid, gets the primary screen ( would return an invalid object if the window handle is invalid).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Screen_.FromObject(System.Object,Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: Gets object of the screen that contains (or is nearest to) the specified object, which can be (depending on variable type): int: 1-based screen index, or Screen_.Primary (0), Screen_.OfMouse, Screen_.OfActiveWindow. Wnd: a window. If invalid, gets primary screen. POINT, Point: a point. RECT, Rectangle: a rectangular area. Screen: a object. If invalid, gets primary screen. null: if w used, gets its screen, else gets primary screen. Other type: throws ArgumentException.
member.remarks: If something fails, gets primary screen. As screen index is used index in the array returned by + 1. It is not the screen index that you can see in Control Panel.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Output.Writer
member.summary: Gets or sets object that actually writes text when your script or the automation library calls Output.Write or Write. If you want to redirect or modify output text (for example write to a file or add time), use code like this: Output.Writer=myWriter;, where myWriter is a variable of your class that is derived from TextWriter and overrides its functions WriteLine, Write and Encoding. It is like redirecting console output with code Console.SetOut(myWriter); (see ). Usually the best place to redirect is in static ScriptClass() { }. Redirection is applied to whole script appdomain, and does not affect other scripts. Redirection affects Write, RedirectConsoleOutput, RedirectDebugOutput, AlwaysOutput and all OutX. It does not affect WriteDirectly and Clear. Don't call Output.Write and Write in your writer class; it would create stack overflow; if need, use Output.WriteDirectly.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Output.WriteDirectly(System.String)
member.summary: Writes string value to the output or console. Unlike other Write methods, this function ignores custom Writer used to redirect output, therefore can be used in your custom writer class.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Output.RedirectConsoleOutput
member.summary: Let Console.WriteX methods write to the output, unless this is a console process (even if AlwaysOutput is true). Console.Write will write line, like Console.WriteLine. Note: Console.Clear will not clear output; it will throw exception; use Output.Clear or try/catch.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Output.RedirectDebugOutput
member.summary: Let Debug.WriteX and Trace.WriteX methods write to the output or console. To write to the output even in console process, set Output.AlwaysOutput=true; before calling this method first time.

member.summary: Access token handle.

member.summary: Gets true if the last called property function failed. Normally getting properties should never fail. Only the GetOfProcess method can fail, then it returns null.

member.summary: UacInfo.IntegrityLevel.

member.summary: UacInfo.Elevation.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.Elevation
member.summary: Gets process UAC elevation type. Elevation types: Full - runs as administrator (High or System integrity level). Limited - runs as standard user (Medium, Medium+UIAccess or Low integrity level) on administrator user session. Default - all processes in this user session run as admin, or all as standard user. Can be: non-administrator user session; service session; UAC is turned off. Unknown - failed to get. Normally it never happens; only GetOfProcess can fail, then it returns null. This property is rarely useful. Instead use other properties of this class.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.IsUIAccess
member.summary: Returns true if the process has uiAccess property. A uiAccess process can access/automate all windows of processes running in the same user session. Most processes don't have this property and cannot access/automate windows of higher integrity level (High, System, Middle+uiAccess) processes and Windows 8 store apps. For example, cannot send keys and Windows messages. Note: High IL (admin) processes also can have this property, therefore IsUIAccess is not the same as IntegrityLevelAndUIAccess==IL.UIAccess (IntegrityLevelAndUIAccess returns IL.UIAccess only for Medium+uiAccess processes; for High+uiAccess processes it returns IL.High). Some Windows API work slightly differently with uiAccess and non-uiAccess admin processes. This property is rarely useful. Instead use other properties of this class.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.IsAppContainer
member.summary: Returns true if the process is a Windows Store app.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.IntegrityLevel
member.summary: Gets process UAC integrity level (IL). IL from lowest to highest value: Untrusted - the most limited rights. Very rare. Low - very limited rights. Used by Internet Explorer tab processes, Windows Store apps. Medium - limited rights. Most processes (unless UAC turned off). UIAccess - Medium IL + can access/automate High IL windows (user interface). Note: Only the property can return UIAccess. This property returns High instead (the same as in Process Explorer). High - most rights. Processes that run as administrator. System - almost all rights. Services, some system processes. Protected - undocumented. Never seen. Unknown - failed to get IL. Never seen. The IL enum member values can be used like if(x.IntegrityLevel > IL.Medium) ... . If UAC is turned off, most non-service processes on administrator account have High IL; on non-administrator - Medium.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.IntegrityLevelAndUIAccess
member.summary: The same as IntegrityLevel, but can return UIAccess.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.GetOfProcess(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Opens process access token and creates UacInfo object that holds it. Returns UacInfo object. Then you can use its properties. Returns null if failed. For example fails for services and some other processes if current process is not administrator. To get UacInfo of this process, instead use UacInfo.ThisProcess.
member.param: Process id. If you have a window, use its ProcessId property.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.ThisProcess
member.summary: Gets UacInfo object of current process.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.IsAdmin
member.summary: Returns true if current process is running as administrator, ie if the user belongs to the local Administrators group and the process is not limited by UAC. This function for example can be used to check whether you can write to protected locations in the file system and registry.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Process_.UacInfo.IsUacDisabled
member.summary: Returns true if UAC is disabled (turned off) on this Windows 7 computer. On Windows 8 and 10 UAC cannot be disabled, although you can disable UAC elevation consent dialogs.

member.name: T:Catkeys.String_
member.summary: Adds extension methods to System.String. Also adds StringComparison.Ordinal[IgnoreCase] versions of .NET String methods that use StringComparison.CurrentCulture by default. See https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms973919.aspx Extension method names have suffix _. Most of these extension methods throw NullReferenceException if called for a string variable that is null.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.Like_(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Compares this string with a string that possibly contains wildcard characters. Returns true if the strings match.
Wildcard characters: * - zero or more of any characters. ? - any character.
member.param: This string. If null, returns true if pattern is null. If "", returns true if pattern is "" or "*".
String that possibly contains wildcard characters. If null, returns true if this string is null. If "", returns true if this string is "". If "*", always returns true except when this string is null.
Case-insensitive.
member.remarks: Like all String_ functions, performs ordinal comparison, ie does not depend on current culture. Much faster than Regex.IsMatch and not much slower than Equals_, EndsWith_, IndexOf_ etc.

member.summary: Calls Like_(patterns[i], ignoreCase) for each wildcard pattern specified in the argument list until one matches this string. Returns 1-based index of matching pattern, or 0 if none.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToInt32_(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Converts part of string to int. Returns the int value, or 0 if fails to convert. Fails to convert when string is null, "", does not begin with a number or the number is too big. Unlike int.Parse and Convert.ToInt32: The number in string can be followed by more text, like "123text". Has startIndex parameter that allows to get number from middle, like "text123text". Gets the end of the number part. No exception when cannot convert. Supports hexadecimal format, like "0x1E" or "0x1e". Much faster.
member.param: Offset in string where to start parsing.
Receives offset in string where the number part ends. If fails to convert, receives 0.
member.remarks: The number can begin with ASCII spaces, tabs or newlines, like " 5". The number can be with "-" or "+", like "-5", but not like "- 5". Fails if the number is greater than +- uint.MaxValue (0xffffffff). The return value becomes negative if the number is greater than int.MaxValue, for example "0xffffffff" is -1, but it becomes correct if assigned to uint (need cast). Does not support non-integer numbers; for example, for "3.5E4" returns 3 and sets numberEndIndex=1.
member.exception: startIndex is less than 0 or greater than string length.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToInt32_(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: This overload does not have parameter numberEndIndex.

member.summary: This overload does not have parameters.

member.summary: Converts part of string to long. Returns the long value, or 0 if fails to convert. Fails to convert when string is null, "", does not begin with a number or the number is too big. Unlike long.Parse and Convert.ToInt64: The number in string can be followed by more text, like "123text". Has startIndex parameter that allows to get number from middle, like "text123text". Gets the end of the number part. No exception when cannot convert. Supports hexadecimal format, like "0x1E" or "0x1e". Much faster.
member.param: Offset in string where to start parsing.
Receives offset in string where the number part ends. If fails to convert, receives 0.
member.remarks: The number can begin with ASCII spaces, tabs or newlines, like " 5". The number can be with "-" or "+", like "-5", but not like "- 5". Fails if the number is greater than +- ulong.MaxValue (0xffffffffffffffff). The return value becomes negative if the number is greater than long.MaxValue, for example "0xffffffffffffffff" is -1, but it becomes correct if assigned to ulong (need cast). Does not support non-integer numbers; for example, for "3.5E4" returns 3 and sets numberEndIndex=1.
member.exception: startIndex is less than 0 or greater than string length.

member.summary: This overload does not have parameter numberEndIndex.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToIntAndString_(System.String,System.String@)
member.summary: Converts string to int (calls ) and gets string part that follows the number. For example, for string "123text" sets the tail variable = "text" and returns 123. For string like "123" sets tail = "". If fails to convert, sets tail = null. Skips 1 ASCII space or tab character after the number part. For example, for string "123 text" sets tail = "text", not " text". Everything else is the same as with ToInt32_.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Wildex
member.summary: This class implements wildcard expression parsing and matching (comparing). Typically used in 'find' functions. For example, Wnd.Find uses it to compare window name, class name and program. The 'find' function creates a Wildex instance (which parses the wildcard expression), then calls for each item (eg window) to compare some its property text.
member.exception: Invalid **options| or regular expression.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wildex.#ctor(System.String)
member.param: Wildcard expression. null will match null. "" will match "".
member.exception: Invalid **options| or regular expression.

member.summary: Creates new Wildex from wildcard expression string. If the string is null, returns null, else creates and returns new Wildex.
member.param: Wildcard expression.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wildex.Match(System.String)
member.summary: Compares a string with the wildcard expression used to create this . Returns true if they match.
member.param: String. If null, returns true if wildcardExpression was null. If "", returns true if it was "" or "*" or a regular expression that matches "".

member.summary: Shows the dialog in new thread and returns without waiting until it is closed.
member.param: A callback function (lambda etc) to call when the dialog closed. It receives TDResult. In what thread it is called: if owner window is specified and it is a Form or Control of this AppDomain and it still exists at that time, calls in its thread; else calls in dialog's thread, which is not this thread.
If true, the dialog disappears when all other threads of this app domain end.
member.remarks: Calls , therefore the dialog is already open when this function returns.
member.exception: Failed to show dialog.

member.name: P:Catkeys.TaskDialog.Result
member.summary: Gets selected button id and other results packed in a TDResult variable. It is the same variable as the ShowDialog return value. If the result is still unavailable (eg the dialog still not closed): If called from the same thread that called ShowDialog, returns null. If called from another thread, waits until the dialog is closed and the return value is available. Note that ShowNoWait calls ShowDialog in another thread.

member.remarks: The returned TDResult variable has these properties: selected button id, selected radio button id, check box state. Tip: TDResult supports implicit cast to int. You can use code switch(TaskDialog.ShowEx(...)) instead of switch(TaskDialog.ShowEx(...).Button) . Tip: For optional parameters use named arguments. Example: TaskDialog.ShowEx("Text.", icon: TDIcon.Info, title: "Title") . This function allows you to use most of the task dialog features, but not all. Alternatively you can create a TaskDialog class instance, set properties and call ShowDialog.

member.name: M:Catkeys.TaskDialog.Show(System.String,System.String,System.String,Catkeys.TDIcon,Catkeys.TDFlags,System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Windows.Forms.Control,Catkeys.Wnd}})
member.summary: Shows task dialog. Returns selected button id.
member.param: Main instruction. Bigger font.
Text below main instruction.

A list of button ids and labels in this format: "id label|id label|...". Example: "1 OK|2 Cancel|5 Save|4 Don't Save". Missing ids are auto-generated, for example "OK|Cancel|100 Custom1|Custom2" is the same as "1 OK|2 Cancel|100 Custom1|101 Custom2". The first in the list button is default, ie responds to the Enter key. For example, "2 No|1 Yes" adds Yes and No buttons and makes No default. Trims newlines around ids and labels. For example, "
1 One
|
2
Two

" is the same as "1 One|2 Two".
To create keyboard shortcuts, use & character in custom button labels. Use && for literal &. Example: "1 &Tuesday[]2 T&hursday[]3 Saturday && Sunday".
There are 6 common buttons: OK, Yes, No, Retry, Cancel, Close. Buttons that have other labels are custom buttons. How common buttons are different: 1. TDFlags.CommandLinks does not change their style. 2. They have keyboard shortcuts that cannot be changed. Inserting & in a label makes it a custom button. 3. Button Cancel can be selected with the Esc key. It also adds X (Close) button in title bar, which selects Cancel. 4. Always displayed in standard order (eg Yes No, never No Yes). But you can for example use "2 No|1 Yes" to set default button = No. 5. The displayed button label is localized, ie different when the Windows UI language is not English.
If omitted, null or "", the dialog will have OK button, id 1. You can use in flags to change the style of custom buttons. See also: .
Owner window or null. See .
member.remarks: Calls . Tip: For optional parameters use named arguments. Example: TaskDialog.Show("Text.", icon: TDIcon.Info) .
member.exception: Failed to show dialog.

member.name: T:Catkeys.CsvTable
member.summary: Parses and composes CSV text. Stores CSV table data in memory as a List of string arrays. CSV is a text format used to store a single table of data in human-readable/editable way. It is a list of lines (called rows or records) containing one or more values (called fields or cells) separated by a separator character. There is no strictly defined CSV standard. CsvTable uses these rules: Fields containg characters (default ','), characters (default '"') and multiple lines must be enclosed in characters. Example: "ab, cd". Each Quote character in such fields must be escaped (replaced) with two characters. Example: "ab ""cd"" ef". Fields that start or end with ASCII space or tab characters must be enclosed in characters, unless is false. Example: " ab ". Rows in CSV text can have different field count.

member.name: M:Catkeys.CsvTable.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance and parses CSV text, the same as . Uses default , and values (',', '"', true).
member.param: CSV text.

member.name: P:Catkeys.CsvTable.Data
member.summary: Gets the internal List containing rows as string arrays. It's not a copy; changing it will change the data of this CsvTable variable. You can do anything with the List. For example, sort it, find rows containing certain field values, get/set field values directly, add/remove rows directly. All row arrays have Length equal to , and it must remain so; you can change Length, but then need to call ColumnCount=newLength.

example.code: x.Data.Sort((a,b) => string.CompareOrdinal(a[0], b[0]));

member.exception: Invalid CSV, eg contains incorrectly enclosed fields.

member.summary: Gets or sets column count. The 'get' function returns the length of all string arrays in the internal List. The 'set' function can add new columns or remove columns at the right.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Wnd
member.summary: A variable of Wnd type represents a native window or control. It contains native window handle, also known as HWND. Wnd functions can be used with windows and controls of any process/thread. Wnd functions also can be used with .NET Form and Control instances, like Wnd w=(Wnd)netControl; w.Method(...); or ((Wnd)netControl).Method(...);.
member.remarks:
There are two main types of windows - top-level windows and controls. Controls are child windows of top-level windows.
More functions are in the nested classes - Wnd.Get, Wnd.Misc, Wnd.Misc.Arrange etc.
What happens when a Wnd function fails:
Functions that get window properties don't throw exceptions. They return false/0/null/empty. Most of them support , and it is mentioned in function documentation.
Many functions that change window properties throw exception. Exceptions are listed in function documentation. Almost all these functions throw only .
Other functions that change window properties return false. They are more often used in programming than in automation scripts.
When a 'find' function does not find the window or control, it returns Wnd0 (window handle 0). Then will return true.
If a function does not follow these rules, it is mentioned in function documentation.
Many functions fail if the window's process has higher UAC integrity level (aministrator, uiAccess) than this process, unless this process has uiAccess level. Especially the functions that change window properties. Some functions that still work: Activate, ActivateLL, ShowMinimized, ShowNotMinimized, ShowNotMinMax, Close.
The Wnd type can be used with native Windows API functions wihout casting. Use Wnd for the parameter type in the declaration, like [DllImport(...)] static extern bool NativeFunction(Wnd hWnd, ...).
See also: MSDN article Window Features.

member.summary: Finds child control. Returns its handle as Wnd. Returns Wnd0 if not found.
member.param: Control name or text. String format: wildcard expression. null means 'any', "" means 'no name'. This function in most cases ignores editable or slow-to-get text unless one of these is used: className, id, ChildFlags.ControlText. Control text often contains an invisible '&' character to underline the next character when using the keyboard to select dialog controls. You can use control name with or without '&', this function supports both.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WndClass.InterDomainRegister(System.String,Catkeys.Native.WNDPROC,System.Int32,System.UInt32,Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WndClass.WndClassEx)
member.summary: Registers new window class that can be used by all app domains of this process. Returns class atom. Calls API RegisterClassEx.
member.param: Class name.
Window procedure. Can be classic window procedure that calls API DefWindowProc. Don't need to protect it from GC. If null, will use DefWindowProc as window procedure.
Size of extra window memory which can be accessed with SetWindowLong/GetWindowLong with >=0 offset. Example: IntPtr.Size.
Class style. Adds CS_GLOBALCLASS.

Can be used to specify API WNDCLASSEX fields not specified in parameters. If not used, the function sets: hCursor = arrow; hbrBackground = COLOR_BTNFACE+1; others = 0/null/Zero. Always uses hInstance=Zero and adds style CS_GLOBALCLASS.
member.exception: Failed, for example if the class already exists and was registered not with this function.
member.remarks: This function can be called multiple times for the same class, for example called once in each app domain. Next time it just returns class atom. Each app domain that calls this function uses its own instance of window procedure delegate. The window class remains registered until this process ends. Don't need to unregister. Thread-safe.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.WaitForAnActiveWindow
member.summary: Waits while there is no active window. It sometimes happens after closing or switching the active window (and the new active window is not of this thread), very briefly until Windows makes the new window active after making the old window inactive (or after closing the old window). Don't need to call this after Activate() and other functions of this library that activate windows. Waits max about 200 ms, then returns false if there is no active window. Processes Windows messages that are in the message queue of this thread.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Misc.AllowActivate
member.summary: Temporarily enables this process to activate windows with API SetForegroundWindow. Returns false if fails (unlikely). In some cases you may need this function because Windows often disables SetForegroundWindow to not allow applications to activate their windows while the user is working (using keyboard/mouse) with the currently active window. Then SetForegroundWindow just makes the window's taskbar button flash which indicates that the windows wants attention. More info: SetForegroundWindow. Usually you don't call SetForegroundWindow directly. It is called by some other functions, for example Form.Show. Don't need to call this function before calling functions of this library that activate windows.

member.summary: Adjusts a rectangle so that it can be used to create a new window that will be entirely in specified screen. By default, 0 and negative x y (r.left r.top) are interpreted as: 0 - screen center, <0 - relative to the right or bottom edge of the screen.
member.param: The rectangle. Initially must contain rectangle coordinates relative to the specified screen. The function replaces them with normal coordinates relative to the primary screen.
Use this screen. If null, use the primary screen. See Screen_.FromObject.
Use the work area, not whole screen.
If rectangle is bigger than screen, resize it.
Don't interpret 0 and negative x y in a special way. They are relative to the top-left corner of the screen.

Similar to RectMoveInScreen, but initial r rectangle coordinates are relative to the primary screen and are not interpreted in a special way. The function adjusts rectangle coordinates to ensure that whole rectangle is in screen.
member.param: The rectangle.

Use the work area, not whole screen.
If rectangle is bigger than screen, resize it.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd._WindowsStoreAppFrameChild(Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: On Win10+, if w is "ApplicationFrameWindow", returns the real app window "Windows.UI.Core.CoreWindow" hosted by w. If w is minimized, cloaked (eg on other desktop) or the app is starting, the "Windows.UI.Core.CoreWindow" is not its child. Then searches for a top-level window with the same name as of w. It is unreliable, but MS does not provide API for this. Info: "Windows.UI.Core.CoreWindow" windows hosted by "ApplicationFrameWindow" belong to separate processes. All "ApplicationFrameWindow" windows belong to a single process.

members.member:
Why Wnd is a struct, not a class: Advantages:
Lightweight. Contains just IntPtr, which is 4 or 8 bytes.
Easier to create overloaded functions that have a window parameter. If it was a class, then a null argument could be ambiguous if eg could also be a string etc.
When a find-window function does not find the window, calling next function (without checking the return value) does not throw null-reference exception. Instead the function can throw a more specific exception or just return false etc.
The handle actually already is a reference (to a window object managed by the OS). We don't own the object; we usually don't need to destroy the window finally; it is more like a numeric window id.
Code where a window argument is Wnd0 is more clear. If if it would be null, then it is unclear how the function interprets it: as a 0 handle or as "don't use it". Now if we want a "don't use it" behavior, we'll use an overload.
In my experience, it makes programming/scripting easier that if it would be a class. Because windows are not found so often (in automation scripts). A find-window function could throw a 'not found' exception, but it is not good (it's easier to check the return value than to use try/catch or throwing/nonthrowing overloads).
Probably it is not a "bad practice" to have a struct with many member functions, because eg the .NET DateTime is a struct.
Disadvantages:
Cannot be a base class of other classes. Workaround: Use it as a public field or property of the other class (or struct); in some cases it can be even better, because Wnd has very many methods, and the non-inherited methods of that class would be difficult to find; now they are separated, and can be used like x.NewClassMethod() and x.w.WndMethod(); anyway, in most cases we'll need the new window classes only for the functions that they add, not for Wnd functions, eg we would use a class ButtonWnd mostly only for button functions, not for general window functions.
In some cases C# does not allow to call a property-set function. Wnd has few such functions.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.IsValid
member.summary: Returns true if the window exists. Returns false if the handle is 0 or invalid. Invalid non-0 handle usually means that the window is closed/destroyed. Calls and API IsWindow.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.IsVisible
member.summary: Gets the visible state. Calls API IsWindowVisible. Returns true if the window is visible. Returns false if is invisible or is a child of invisible parent. This function is unaware about cloaked windows. If need, use code if(w.IsVisible && !w.IsCloaked). This function is unaware about transparent windows, zero-size windows, zero-window-region windows, off-screen windows and windows that are completely covered by other windows.
member.remarks: Also returns false when fails (eg window closed or 0 handle). Supports .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Show(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Shows (if hidden) or hides this window. Does not activate/deactivate/zorder. With windows of current thread usually it's better to use ShowLL.
member.remarks: Calls API ShowWindow with SW_SHOWNA or SW_HIDE.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ShowLL(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Shows (if hidden) or hides this window. Does not activate/deactivate/zorder.
member.remarks:
This library has two similar functions - Show and ShowLL. Show is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. ShowLL usually is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. ShowLL is more low-level. Does not throw exception when fails, and does not add a delay. Show adds a small delay when the window is of other thread.
Calls API ShowWindow with SW_SHOWNA or SW_HIDE.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.ActiveWindow
member.summary: Gets the foreground window. Calls API GetForegroundWindow.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.IsActive
member.summary: Returns true if this window is the foreground window.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Activate
member.summary: Activates this window (brings to the foreground). Also unhides, restores minimized etc, to ensure that the window is ready to receive sent keys, mouse clicks ect.
member.remarks:
Activating a window usually also uncloaks it, for example switches to its virtual desktop on Windows 10. Fails (throws exception) if cannot activate this window, except:
If this is a control, activates its top-level parent window.
If this is Wnd.Get.VirtualDesktopWindow, just deactivates the currently active window.
When the target application instead activates another window of the same thread.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Activate(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Activates this window (brings to the foreground). The same as , but this overload has some options.
member.param: Don't activate if has WS_EX_NOACTIVATE style or is toolwindow without caption, unless cloaked. Then returns true.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ActivateLL
member.summary: Low-level version of . Just calls , API SetForegroundWindow and makes sure that it actually worked, but does not check whether it activated exactly this window. No exceptions, does not unhide, does not restore minimized, does not check is it a top-level window or control, etc. Returns false if fails.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.LibAllowActivate(System.Boolean)
member.summary: No exceptions.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd._AllowActivate_SendKey(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sends a key (VK_0 up). It allows to activate now. Later this process can always activate easily (without key etc). It works even with higher IL windows. Don't know why is this behavior. Tested on all OS from XP to 10. Does not work if the foreground process has higher UAC IL.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd._AllowActivate_MinRes
member.summary: Creates a temporary minimized window and restores it. It activates the window and allows us to activate. Then sets 'no active window' to prevent auto-activating another window when destroying the temporary window.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd._AllowActivate_AllowSetFore
member.summary: Calls Api.AllowSetForegroundWindow(Api.GetCurrentProcessId()).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.FocusControl
member.summary: Makes this control the focused (receiving keyboard input) control. Also activetes its top-level parent window (see ). This control can belong to any process/thread. To focus controls of this thread usually it's better to use ; it is lightweight, no exceptions.
member.exception: Invalid handle, or failed to set focus, or failed to activate parent window.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.FocusControlOfThisThread
member.summary: Makes this control the focused (receiving keyboard input) control. This control must belong to this thread, else nothing happens. Its top-level parent window should be the active window, else nothing happens. Calls API SetFocus.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.IsFocusedControl

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.MoveLL(System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.UInt32)
member.summary: Moves and/or resizes.
member.remarks:
This library has two similar functions - Move and MoveLL. Move is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. MoveLL usually is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. MoveLL is more low-level than Move (which can throw exceptions, supports fractional/workarea coordinates, restores if min/max, does not support SWP_ flags).
Calls API SetWindowPos. Supports .
For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.
member.param: Left. Can be null to not move in X axis.
Top. Can be null to not move in Y axis.
Width. Can be null to not change width.
Height. Can be null to not change height.
One or more Native.SWP_ flags, except SWP_NOMOVE, SWP_NOSIZE, SWP_NOZORDER, SWP_NOOWNERZORDER, SWP_NOACTIVATE.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.MoveLL(System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Moves. Calls MoveLL(x, y, null, null, 0).
member.remarks:
This library has two similar functions - Move and MoveLL. Move is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. MoveLL usually is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. MoveLL is more low-level than Move (which can throw exceptions, supports fractional/workarea coordinates, restores if min/max).
Calls API SetWindowPos. Supports .
For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.
member.param: Left. Can be null to not move in X axis.
Top. Can be null to not move in Y axis.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ResizeLL(System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Resizes. Calls MoveLL(null, null, width, height, 0).
member.remarks:
This library has two similar functions - Resize and ResizeLL. Resize is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. ResizeLL usually is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. ResizeLL is more low-level than Resize (which can throw exceptions, supports fractional/workarea coordinates, restores if min/max).
Calls API SetWindowPos. Supports .
For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.
member.param: Width. Can be null to not change width.
Height. Can be null to not change height.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Move(System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Int32,System.Single}},System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Int32,System.Single}},System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Int32,System.Single}},System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Int32,System.Single}},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves and/or resizes. With windows of current thread usually it's better to use MoveLL.
member.param: Left. Can be int (pixels) or float (fraction of screen or work area or direct parent client area) or null to not move in X axis.
Top. Can be int (pixels) or float (fraction of screen or work area or direct parent client area) or null to not move in Y axis.
Width. Can be int (pixels) or float (fraction of screen or work area or direct parent client area) or null to not change width.
Height. Can be int (pixels) or float (fraction of screen or work area or direct parent client area) or null to not change height.
If false, the coordinates are relative to the primary screen, else to its work area. Not used when this is a child window.
member.remarks: Also restores the visible top-level window if it is minimized or maximized. For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Move(System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Int32,System.Single}},System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Int32,System.Single}},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves. Calls Move(x, y, null, null, workArea). With windows of current thread usually it's better to use MoveLL.
member.param: Left. Can be int (pixels) or float (fraction of screen or work area or direct parent client area) or null to not move in X axis.
Top. Can be int (pixels) or float (fraction of screen or work area or direct parent client area) or null to not move in Y axis.
If false, the coordinates are relative to the primary screen, else to its work area. Not used when this is a child window.
member.remarks: Also restores the visible top-level window if it is minimized or maximized. For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Resize(System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Int32,System.Single}},System.Nullable{Catkeys.Types{System.Int32,System.Single}},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Resizes. Calls Move(null, null, width, height, workArea). With windows of current thread usually it's better to use ResizeLL.
member.param: Width. Can be int (pixels) or float (fraction of screen or work area or direct parent client area) or null to not change width.
Height. Can be int (pixels) or float (fraction of screen or work area or direct parent client area) or null to not change height.
If false, fractional width/height are part of the primary screen, else of its work area. Not used when this is a child window.
member.remarks: Also restores the visible top-level window if it is minimized or maximized.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.MoveInScreen(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Object,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves this window to coordinates x y in specified screen, and ensures that entire window is in screen. By default, 0 and negative x y are interpreted as: 0 - screen center, <0 - relative to the right or bottom edge of the screen.
member.param: X coordinate in the specified screen.
Y coordinate in the specified screen.
Move to this screen. If null, use screen of this window. The same as with .
Use the work area, not whole screen.
If window is bigger than screen, resize it.
Don't interpret 0 and negative x y in a special way. They are relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
member.remarks: If the window is maximized, minimized or hidden, it will have the new position and size when restored, not immediately, except when moving maximized to another screen.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.EnsureInScreen(System.Object,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves this window if need, to ensure that entire window is in screen.
member.param: Move to this screen. If null, use screen of this window. See Screen_.FromObject.
Use the work area, not whole screen.
If window is bigger than screen, resize it.
member.remarks: If the window is maximized, minimized or hidden, it will have the new position and size when restored, not immediately.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.MoveToScreenCenter(System.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves this window to the center of the screen. Calls MoveInScreen(0, 0, screen, workArea). Also makes not minimized/maximized/hidden.
member.param: Move to this screen. If null, use screen of this window. See Screen_.FromObject.
Use the work area, not whole screen.

member.summary: Places this window before window w in the Z order. Also can make this window topmost or non-topmost, depending on where w is in the Z order. This window and w can be both top-level windows or both controls of same parent. May not work with top-level windows when it would move an inactive window above the active window. If w is Wnd0, calls .
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ZorderBelow(Catkeys.Wnd)

This window and w can be both top-level windows or both controls of same parent. May not work with top-level windows when it would move an inactive window above the active window. If w is Wnd0, calls .
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ZorderTop
member.summary: Places this window or control at the top of the Z order. If the window was topmost, it will be at the top of topmost windows, else at the top of non-topmost windows (after topmost windows). Does not activate. In most cases does not work with top-level inactive windows; instead use .
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ZorderBottom

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ZorderTopmost
member.summary: Makes this window topmost (always on top of non-topmost windows in the Z order). Does not activate. If this window has an owner window, the owner does not become topmost. Thic cannot be a control.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ZorderNotopmost(System.Boolean)

If is true, calls API GetWindowThreadProcessId, OpenProcess and IsWow64Process. If you know that the window belongs to current process, instead use or IntPtr.Size==8. This function is much slower.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.IsHung
member.summary: Returns true if thread of this window is considered hung (not responding). Calls API IsHungAppWindow.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.IsHungGhost
member.summary: Returns true if the window is a ghost window that the system creates over a hung (not responding) window to allow the user to minimally interact with it.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.IsConsole
member.summary: Returns true if this is a console window (class name "ConsoleWindowClass").
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.IsUacAccessDenied
member.summary: Returns true if UAC would not allow to automate the window. It happens when current process has lower UAC integrity level and is not uiAccess, unless UAC is turned off.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.ClassName
member.summary: Gets class name. Returns null if fails, eg if the window is closed. Supports .

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets window name or control text. The 'get' function returns "" if the text is empty. Returns null if fails, eg if the window is closed. Supports .
member.remarks: Each top-level window and control has a text property, although the text can be empty. This function gets or sets that text. If this is a top-level window, it is the title bar text. If control, it is the text displayed in the control, eg button text, static text, edit control text. However most other controls don't have text that we can get with this function, even if they display text. It is not the .NET Control.Name property. The 'get' function calls API InternalGetWindowText. If it returns empty text and this is a control, calls GetControlText, which is slow; to avoid it use GetControlName instead of Name. The 'set' function calls SetControlText.
member.exception: Failed (only 'set' function).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.GetControlName(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets control name. Returns "" if it is empty. Returns null if fails, eg if the control is destroyed. Supports .
member.param: Remove '&' characters that are used to underline next character when using the keyboard to select controls.
member.remarks: Similar to the property, and in most cases will get the same value. Unlike Name, never calls GetControlText. Can be used with top-level windows too.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.GetControlText
member.summary: Gets control text. Returns "" if it is empty. Returns null if fails, eg if the control is destroyed or its thread is hung. Supports .
member.remarks: Similar to the property, and in most cases will get the same value. Unlike Name, does not try to use the fast API InternalGetWindowText(), which in some cases can get unexpected value. Sends message WM_GETTEXT. It is much slower than InternalGetWindowText, especially when the window is of another thread. Can be used with top-level windows too.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.SetControlText(System.String)
member.summary: Sets control text.
member.param: Text. Can be null, it is the same as "".
member.remarks: Sends message WM_SETTEXT. More info: see GetControlText. Can be used with top-level windows too. You can instead use the property, which calls this function with default timeout.
member.exception: Failed, for example the window is hung.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ClassNameIs(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if the class name of this window matches className. Else returns false. Also returns false if 0 handle or fails to get class name. Supports .
member.param: Class name. Case-insensitive wildcard.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.ClassNameIs(System.String[])
member.summary: If the class name of this window matches one of strings in classNames, returns 1-based index of the string. Else returns 0. Also returns 0 if 0 handle or fails to get class name. Supports .
member.param: Class names. Case-insensitive wildcard.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.ProcessName
member.summary: Gets filename (without ".exe") of process executable file. Return null if fails. Calls and Process_.GetProcessName.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.ProcessPath
member.summary: Gets full path of process executable file. Return null if fails. Calls and Process_.GetProcessName.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Wnd.WindowsFormsControlName
member.summary: Gets the programming name of a Windows Forms control. Returns null if it is not a Windows Forms control or if fails. Use this with controls of other processes. Don't use with your controls, when you have a Control object. This is slow when getting names of multiple controls in a window. Instead create a instance and call its method for each control.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Close(System.Nullable{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Tries to close the window. The window may refuse to be closed. For example, it may be hung, or hide itself instead, or display a "Save?" message box, or simply need more time until it is finally destroyed. This function waits a while until the window is destroyed or hidden or disabled, but does not wait indefinitely. If finally the window is destroyed (or was already destroyed when calling this function), sets this=Wnd0 and returns true. Else returns false (although in many cases the window is already hidden and will be destroyed soon, and another window is activated). If the window is of this thread, just sends (not posts, use CloseLL for it) message WM_CLOSE or WM_SYSCOMMAND and does not wait.
member.param: If true, uses API WM_SYSCOMMAND, like when the user clicks the Close button in the title bar. If false, uses API WM_CLOSE, which is more often used in programming code. If null, uses API WM_SYSCOMMAND or WM_CLOSE depending on window style. Most windows can be closed with any of these messages, but some respond properly only to one of them.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.CloseLL(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sends or posts WM_CLOSE message.
member.param: Use PostMessage. This function does not wait until the window is closed.
member.remarks:
There are several 'close window' functions:
CloseLL is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread or process.
Close is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process.
can be used only with native windows of current thread.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.CloseAll(System.String,System.String,System.Object,Catkeys.Wnd.WinFlags,System.Func{Catkeys.Wnd,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Closes all matching windows. Calls FindAll. All parameters etc are the same. Then calls Close for each found window. Returns the number of found windows.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Find(System.String,System.String,System.Object,Catkeys.Wnd.WinFlags,System.Func{Catkeys.Wnd,System.Boolean},System.Int32)
member.summary: Finds window. Returns its handle as Wnd. Returns Wnd0 if not found.
member.param: Window name. Usually it is the title bar text. String format: wildcard expression. null means 'any', "" means 'no name'.
Window class name. String format: wildcard expression. null means 'any'.

Depends on type and flags:
null - not used.
string - program file name without ".exe". String format: wildcard expression.
Wnd - owner window. See .
int - process id. If using flag ThreadId - thread id. See GetWindowThreadProcessId.
uint - the same as int.
Lambda etc callback function to call for each matching window. It can evaluate more properties of the window and return true when they match. Example: t => t.HasStyle(Native.WS_CAPTION).
1-based index of matching window. For example, if matchIndex is 2, the function skips the first matching window and returns the second.
member.remarks: If there are multiple matching windows, gets the first in the Z order matching window, preferring visible windows. On Windows 8 and later finds only desktop windows, not Windows Store app Metro-style windows (on Windows 10 only few such windows exist), unless this process has uiAccess; to find such windows you can use Wnd.FindRaw.
member.exception: className is ""; programEtc is ""; programEtc is 0; programEtc type mismatch. To match any, use null.

example.code: Wnd w=Wnd.Find("Name"); if(w.Is0) Print("not found");

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.FindRaw(System.String,System.String,Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: Finds window by class name and optionally name. Calls API FindWindowEx. Faster than Find, which uses API EnumWindows, but slower when used in a loop to enumerate all windows. Does not skip hidden and cloaked windows, and does not prefer visible windows like Find().
member.param: Class name. Full, case-insensitive. Wildcard etc not supported. Can be null to match any.
Name. Full, case-insensitive. Wildcard etc not supported. Can be omitted or null to match any.
If used, starts searching from the next window in the Z order.

member.param: Need only visible windows.
Place all list elements of hidden windows at the end of the returned list, even if the hidden windows are before some visible windows in the Z order.
member.remarks: On Windows 8 and later gets only desktop windows, not Windows Store app Metro-style windows (on Windows 10 only few such windows exist), unless this process has uiAccess; to get such windows you can use Wnd.FindRaw.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Wnd.Get.NextMainWindow(Catkeys.Wnd,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets next window in the Z order, skipping invisible and other windows that would not be added to taskbar or not activated by Alt+Tab. Returns Wnd0 if there are no such windows.
member.param: Window after (behind) which to search. If omitted or Wnd0, starts from the top of the Z order.
If wFrom is used and there are no matching windows after it, retry from the top of the Z order. Like Alt+Tab does. Can return wFrom.
Skip minimized windows.
On Windows 10 include windows on all virtual desktops. On Windows 8 include Windows Store apps (only if this process has uiAccess).

Emulate Alt+Tab behavior with owned windows (message boxes, dialogs): If wFrom is such owned window, skip its owner. If the found window has an owned window that was active more recently, return that owned window.
member.remarks: This function is quite slow and does not exactly match the behavior of Windows taskbar and Alt+Tab, because there is no API for this. NextMainWindow(Wnd.ActiveWindow, retryFromTop:true, likeAltTab:true) ideally should get the same window as would be activated by Alt+Tab. Without retryFromTop:true, likeAltTab:true this function can be used to get main application windows like in taskbar. It is used by All.MainWindows.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Registry_
member.summary: Registry functions. Extends Microsoft.Win32.Registry.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Registry_.CatkeysKey
member.summary: Default registry key, used when the key argument is null or @"\" or starts with @"\".

member.name: M:Catkeys.Registry_.ParseKeyString(System.String@)
member.summary: Parses registry key string and returns hive as RegistryKey. If key starts with "HKEY_", removes hive name from it and returns that hive. For example, if key is @"HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Test", sets key=@"Software\Test" and returns Registry.LocalMachine. Else if key is null or @"\", sets key=Registry_.CatkeysKey (@"Software\Catkeys\User") and returns Registry.CurrentUser. Else if key starts with @"\", prepends Registry_.CatkeysKey (@"Software\Catkeys\User") and returns Registry.CurrentUser. Else just returns Registry.CurrentUser. Valid hive names: "HKEY_CURRENT_USER", "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE", "HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT", "HKEY_USERS", "HKEY_PERFORMANCE_DATA" or "HKEY_CURRENT_CONFIG".
member.param: Registry key. Can start with a hive name.
member.exception: 'key' starts with "HKEY_" but it is an invalid hive name.

member.summary: Memory shared by all appdomains of current process. Size 0x10000 (64 KB). Initially zero.
member.remarks: When need to prevent simultaneous access of the memory by multiple threads, use lock("uniqueString"){...} . It locks in all appdomains, because literal strings are interned, ie shared by all appdomains. Using some other object with 'lock' would lock only in that appdomain. However use this only in single module, because ngened modules have own interned strings.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.Work

member.summary: Waits until all submitted instances of the callback function finish their work. While waiting, this thread cannot dispatch events and Windows messages.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.Work.Cancel
member.summary: Waits until all running instances of the callback function finish their work, and cancels pending (still not running) instances. While waiting, this thread cannot dispatch events and Windows messages.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.Work.Dispose
member.summary: Calls , releases all resources used by this object and allows this object to be garbage-collected. Call this to avoid memory leaks. If not called, the object and related OS object remain in memory until this appdomain ends.

member.summary: Retrieves and dispatches messages from the message queue of current thread. Similar to Application.DoEvents, but more lightweight. Just calls API PeekMessage, TranslateMessage and DispatchMessage. Returns false if received WM_QUIT message (reposts it), else returns true.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Time.SetTimer(System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Action{Catkeys.Time.Timer_},System.Object)
member.summary: Sets new timer for this thread. Returns new Timer_ object that can be used to change or stop the timer if you want to do it not in the callback function; usually don't need it.
member.param: Time interval (period) of calling the callback function, milliseconds. Min interval is 10; if this parameter is 0-9, uses 10. Max interval is int.MaxValue.
Call the callback function once, not repeatedly. The timer will be stopped before calling the callback function.
A callback function (delegate), for example lambda.
Something to pass to the callback function as Timer_.Tag.
member.remarks: Uses class Time.Timer_, which calls API SetTimer. Similar to System.Windows.Forms.Timer, but more lightweight, for example does not create a hidden window. The callback function will be called in this thread. This thread must have a message loop, eg call Application.Run() or Form.ShowModal() or TaskDialog.Show(). The callback function is not called while this thread is not retrieving Windows messages from the thread's message queue. The timer interval precision is 10-16 ms.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Time.Timer_
member.summary: Manages a timer for this thread. Calls API SetTimer and API KillTimer. Similar to System.Windows.Forms.Timer, but more lightweight, for example does not create a hidden window. Used by Time.SetTimer, more info there.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance. Used by .

member.summary: Starts timer. If already started, resets and changes its period.
member.param: Time interval (period) of calling the callback function, milliseconds.
Call the callback function once, not repeatedly. The timer will be stopped before calling the callback function.
member.remarks: If already started, this function must be called in same thread.
member.exception: API SetTimer returned 0. Unlikely.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Time.Timer_.Stop
member.summary: Stops the timer.
member.remarks: Your callback function will never be called after this, even if a timer period is elapsed. Later you can call Start() again. Calling Stop() is optional. Must be called in same thread.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Time.SystemWaitPrecision
member.summary: This class changes the precision of various wait functions. Actually it is the Windows thread scheduling period, and is applied to all threads in all processes. Normal period is 15.625 ms (1/64 s), minimal 2 ms, but it depends on OS version. This class allows you to temporarily make it smaller than the current period when you need better precision. The period is revoked when disposing the variable. See example. The system uses the smallest period (highest precision) that currently is set by any application. This does not change the precision of SetTimer.

member.param: Requested period. Should be 2 - 16.
member.exception: timeBeginPeriod failed.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Path_

member.name: M:Catkeys.Path_.ExpandEnvVar(System.String)
member.summary: If path starts with '%' character, expands environment variables enclosed in %, else just returns path.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Path_.IsFullPath(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if path matches one of these wildcard patterns: @"\\*" - network path. @"[A-Z]:\*" - local path. @"[A-Z]:" - drive name. @"%*%*" - environment variable (usually contains a full path). @"<*>*" - special string that can be used with some functions of this library. @":*" - eg shell object CLSID like "::{CLSID}" Also returns true if path looks like a URL (any protocol), eg "http://abc" or "http:" or "shell:abc". Note: don't use "filename:stream" unless it is full path.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Path_.MakeFullPath(System.String)
member.summary: Makes fully-qualified path. If path is not full path, returns + path. Calls Combine, which expands environment variables, processes @"..\" etc.
member.param: Full path or filename or relative path.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Path_.Combine(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Combines two paths and makes fully-qualified path. Similar to Path.Combine (.NET function), but not the same.
member.remarks: Returns fully-qualified path, with processed @"..\" etc, not relative, not short (DOS), with replaced environment variables if starts with "%". If the return value would not be full path, prepends . If s1 and s2 are null or "", returns "". No exceptions.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Path_.IsURL(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if path is or begins with an internet protocol, eg "http://www.x.com" or "http:". The protocol can be unknown, the function just checks string format.
member.param: A file path or URL or any other string.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Path_.CorrectFileName(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Replaces characters that cannot be used in file names. Also corrects other forms of invalid or problematic filename (except invalid length): trims spaces and other blank characters; replaces "." at the end; prepends "@" if a reserved name like "CON" or "CON.txt". Returns valid filename. Returns null if name is null. Returns "" if name is "" or contains just blank characters. Does not check name length; no correction or exception if it is 0 (or null) or greater than max filename length which is less than max path length 259.
member.param: Initial filename.
A string that will replace each invalid character. Default "-".

member.name: M:Catkeys.Path_.Internal.IsExtension(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if path is like ".ext" and the ext part does not contain characters ".\\/:".

member.name: M:Catkeys.Path_.Internal.IsProtocol(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if path is like "protocol:" and not like "c:".

member.summary: Finds file or directory and returns full and fully-qualified path. Returns null if cannot be found. If the path argument is not full path, searches in these places: 1. dirs, if used. 2. . 3. Calls API SearchPath, which searches in process directory, Windows system directories, current directory, PATH environment variable. 4. If path ends with ".exe", tries to get path from registry "App Paths" keys.

member.summary: Gets or sets a non-file-system target (eg Control Panel) through its ITEMIDLIST. Use Marshal.FreeCoTaskMem() to free the return value of the 'get' function.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Files.Misc
member.summary: Miscellaneous functions.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Files.Misc.PidlFromString(System.String)
member.summary: Converts file path or URL or shell object parsing name to PIDL. Later call Marshal.FreeCoTaskMem();

member.name: M:Catkeys.Files.Misc.PidlToString(System.IntPtr,Catkeys.Native.SIGDN)
member.summary: Converts PIDL to file path or URL or shell object parsing name. Returns null if pidl is Zero or failed.
member.param: A value from the enumeration that specifies the type of string to retrieve. With the default value returns string that can be passed to PidlFromString. It can be a path, URL, "::{CLSID}", etc. Other often used values: Native.SIGDN.SIGDN_FILESYSPATH - returns null if pidl is not of a file system object. Native.SIGDN.SIGDN_URL - returns null if pidl is not of a URL or path. If path, returns its URL form, like "file:///C:/a/b.txt". Native.SIGDN.SIGDN_NORMALDISPLAY - returns string that is best to display in UI but cannot be passed to PidlFromString.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Icons.GetFileIconImage(System.String,System.Int32,Catkeys.Icons.IconFlags)

member.param: Any file, folder, URL like "http://..." or "shell:..." etc, shell item like "::{CLSID}" or "::{CLSID1}\::{CLSID2}". Also can be a file type like ".txt" or a protocol like "http:". If it is a file containing multiple icons (eg exe, dll), can be specified icon index like "path,index" or native icon resource id like "path,-id". If not full path, the file must be in program's folder.
Icon width and height. Also can be enum , cast to int.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Icons.AsyncIcons
member.summary: Gets file icons asynchronously. Use to avoid waiting until all icons are extracted before displaying them in a UI (menu etc). Instead you show the UI without icons, and then asynchronously receive icons when they are extracted. At first call for each file. Then call GetAllAsync. Create a callback function of type and pass its delegate to GetAllAsync.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Icons.AsyncIcons.Add(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Adds a file path to an internal collection.
member.param: File path etc to pass to .
Something to pass to your callback function together with icon handle for this file.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Icons.AsyncIcons.Add(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Catkeys.Icons.AsyncIn})
member.summary: Adds multiple file paths to an internal collection. The same as calling Add(string, object) multiple times. This function copies the list.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Icons.AsyncIcons.Count
member.summary: Gets the number of items added with Add(). GetAllAsync() sets it = 0.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Icons.AsyncIcons.GetAllAsync(Catkeys.Icons.AsyncCallback,System.Int32,Catkeys.Icons.IconFlags,System.Object)
member.summary: Starts getting icons of files added with Add(). After this function returns, icons are asynchronously extracted with , and callback called with icon handle (or Zero if failed). The callback is called in this thread. This thread must have a message loop (eg Application.Run()). If you'll need more icons, you can call Add() and GetAllAsync() again with the same AsyncIcons instance, even if getting old icons if still not finished.
member.param: A callback function delegate.
Icon width and height. Also can be enum , cast to int.
Something to pass to callback functions.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Icons.AsyncIcons.Clear
member.summary: Clears the internal collection of file paths added with Add().

member.name: M:Catkeys.Icons.AsyncIcons.Cancel
member.summary: Stops getting icons and calling callback functions.

member.summary: Creates new object with all the same option values. Code var o2=o1.Copy(); does the same as var o2=new ScriptOptions(o1); .

member.name: P:Catkeys.ScriptOptions.Default
member.summary: Default options used by: All threads of current script's appdomain; New ScriptOptions objects created like var o=new ScriptOptions();. Initially default speed is 100, other options false/0/null. You can modify them in scripts and script templates. Do it in ScriptClass static constructor.

example.code: static ScriptClass() { ScriptOptions.Default.speed=50; } //constructor ... Print(Option.speed); //speed of this thread Option.speed=10; //changes only for this thread
